title: Panel on Data Protection and Security on the Web

panelist: Harith Alani, Knowledge Media Institute (KMI), Open University (OU)

segmentation: So when Valentina asked me to sit on this panel, I told it would look like I don't really do any work with privacy and security.
But obviously she knows that, but it's because I moaned a little bit about that.
In the summer school last year, I think.
So she dragged me to this panel to say something about that.
So could you could I see raise of hands of those who do collect and analyze social media data?
I probably know most of you.
Right, so quite a few.
So how many of you did that in full compliance with European Commission data protection directives and the terms and conditions of the year, right?
You don't even do social media.
So I think that's the point.
I could just it doesn't happen.
So I could probably go quiet now because that's that's that's the only point I wanted to make.
But if you look at the number of oh.
Right see so.
If you look at the number of projects this note scrolling, that's OK.
There's a very long list of projects that have been funded which are partly or wholly dependent on data from social media, and I have quite a few of those.
And if you look at the number of papers that have been published, not even submitted, you could see it's a really exponential growth.
And this is only a fraction of those papers.
And we tend to moan a little bit about how all these social media systems they have all our data there.
You know, way too much about it.
They don't really tell us what they're going to do with it.
But then there's only about a second time difference between them.
Releasing an API and US collecting as much data as we can from all of them.
Because we want to do some cool research and cool science and not just US researchers, but also there are so many businesses entirely dependent on that on that sector.
So for example, you know Facebook.
They released a little bit of semantics.
They did this this graph and now we can learn lots of very sensitive information.
Such as how many people here are interested in that controversial magazine?
Well, there are 2200 two 128 of us apparently there.
That's OK, and how many of us are interested in cannabis as well as semantic web?
Quite a few.
Some of them are here.
Perhaps we'll talk later.
Given that this is years WC how many interested in belly dancing at the semantic web?
You need to be older to know this this history.
So again there are quite a few here.
Not only that I could filter the search much more precisely, so I could say how many interested in whatever belongs to certain Institute or with that with certain educational history and so on.
Given that.
It just came out of a very another controversial European election, so these are the main parties in the UK.
And I just search how many people like these parties, each one and like racism.
And you know, if you're if you're from the UK, you would see that you could really learn probably an accurate.
Thing about these parties and their associations with certain interests.
Now again, Facebook is not accurate in many cases.

I talked to one person who apparently was the first hit and those who would like belly dancing and ears WC and he said, well, actually I don't even know I'm on that list is just happened that he had a friend who teaches belly dancing and he he liked that page.
So obviously he's got very more more interesting friends than I do.
But also it's just not aware of these things that we can get as researchers, we can just collect.

And if you've been lucky enough to be funded, again, this is meant to scroll to show you the length of that document that if you've been lucky enough to get funded from the European Commission and you're doing some analysis with social media, you will have to comply with that list.
It's a reasonable list.
You know there are quite a few things that you need to do.
Eliminate minors.
You need to have a procedure for data protection, security, etc etc.
Is it enough or not?
That's another question.
For the other panelists, but for me I am not a lawyer.
I don't know about these things, I just want to do analysis of data.
And in the past we've talked to some lawyers to help us understand all of that.
They gave us a 200 page document explaining some of these things, and with every clause there is, well, it depends.
And of course, if you talk to another lawyer, they will give you a completely different 200 page documents and so my.
So my dilemma is how can I continue?
How can we all?
How can these businesses continue to do what they're doing?
But to do them a little bit more lawfully and without having to go and get a degree in load to understand all of these things?
Are there things that we can come together to up to the experts and create some sort of tools and procedures that will help us to do that without pissing off to many other people?
